qas.question: What type of relationship harms both organisms?
What is the ultimate result of synnecrosis?
How common is synnecrosis in the natural world?
Why do bees sting even though it will kill them?
What happens if a bee does not protect the hive?
What is a common type of symbiosis in which the interaction between species is detrimental to both organisms involved?
What does the long enduring condition and the interaction eventually cause?
What always happens to the victims of the bee sting?
What happens if the bee does not die?

context: <a0_0><b4_0><b5_0><b8_0>Synnecrosis<b8_0/><b5_0/><b4_0/><a0_0/> is a rare type of symbiosis in which the interaction between species is detrimental to both organisms involved. It is a short-lived condition, as the interaction eventually causes <a1_0><b6_0><b7_0>death<b7_0/><b6_0/><a1_0/>. Because of this, evolution selects against synnecrosis and it is <a2_0>uncommon<a2_0/> in nature. An example of this is the relationship between some species of bees and victims of the bee sting. Species of bees who die after stinging their prey inflict pain on themselves (albeit <a3_0>to protect the hive<a3_0/>) as well as on the victim. This term is rarely used.
